name: Q["return"]
doc:
Throws a ReturnValue exception to stop an asynchronous generator.

This interface is a stop-gap measure to support generator return values in older Firefox/SpiderMonkey. In browsers that support ES6 generators like Chromium 29, just use "return" in your generator functions.

params.name: value
params.doc: the return value for the surrounding generator

throws.doc: ReturnValue exception with the value. @example // ES6 style Q.async(function* () { var foo = yield getFooPromise(); var bar = yield getBarPromise(); return foo + bar; }) // Older SpiderMonkey style Q.async(function () { var foo = yield getFooPromise(); var bar = yield getBarPromise(); Q.return(foo + bar); })

members.doc: Invokes a method in a future turn.

params.name: object
params.doc: promise or immediate reference for target object

params.name: name
params.doc: name of method to invoke

params.name: value
params.doc: a value to post, typically an array of invocation arguments for promises that are ultimately backed with resolve values, as opposed to those backed with URLs wherein the posted value can be any JSON serializable object.

members.short_doc: Invokes a method in a future turn. ...

members.doc: sends a message to a value in a future turn

params.name: op

params.name: args

return.name: return
return.doc: result {Promise} a promise for the result of the operation

members.short_doc: Gets the value of a property in a future turn. ...

members.name: promised
members.doc:
The promised function decorator ensures that any promise arguments are settled and passed as values (this is also settled and passed as a value). It will also ensure that the result of a function is always a promise.

@example var add = Q.promised(function (a, b) { return a + b; }); add(Q(a), Q(B));

params.name: callback
params.doc: The function to decorate
